E-commerce technology stacks are sets of tools and technologies used to build and run an online store. These stacks typically include a combination of front-end technologies, such as HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, which are used to create the user interface of the website, and back-end technologies, such as databases, servers, and application programming interfaces (APIs), which handle the behind-the-scenes functionality of the website.
what are parts of ecommerce business like marketing, analitycs...

There are many different aspects to an e-commerce business, including but not limited to:

1. Marketing: This involves promoting the business and its products to potential customers through a variety of channels, such as search engine optimization (SEO), pay-per-click (PPC) advertising, social media marketing, email marketing, and content marketing.
2. Analytics: This involves tracking and analyzing data about the business, such as website traffic, customer behavior, and sales trends, to gain insights and make data-driven decisions.
3. Product management: This involves sourcing and managing the inventory of products that are sold through the online store, including sourcing, pricing, and fulfillment.
4. Customer service: This involves providing support to customers before, during, and after their purchase, such as answering questions, processing returns, and handling complaints.
5. Payment processing: This involves accepting and processing payments from customers, including handling payment methods such as credit cards, debit cards, and online payment services like PayPal.
6. Shipping and fulfillment: This involves packaging and delivering products to customers, as well as handling returns and exchanges.
7. Accounting and finance: This involves managing the financial aspects of the business, such as tracking income and expenses, calculating taxes, and preparing financial statements.

In addition to these core functions, there may be other aspects of an e-commerce business, depending on the specific needs and goals of the business. For example, some businesses may have a physical storefront in addition to their online store, and would need to manage operations for that storefront as well. Others may offer custom or personalized products, and would need to manage the production and fulfillment of those products.
full list of questions to ask when creating marketing strategy

When creating a marketing strategy, there are many different questions you may want to ask to ensure that your strategy is effective and aligns with your business goals. Some examples of questions you may want to ask include:

* What are our target customers and what are their needs, preferences, and pain points?
* What are our unique selling points and how do they differentiate us from our competitors?
* What are our business goals and how does our marketing strategy support them?
* What channels will we use to reach our target customers and why?
* What message will we communicate to our target customers and why?
* What is our budget and how will we allocate it across different marketing channels?
* How will we measure the success of our marketing efforts and what metrics will we use?
* How will we adapt our marketing strategy based on data and feedback?
* What potential challenges and obstacles might we face and how will we overcome them?

Answering these and other relevant questions can help you develop a comprehensive and effective marketing strategy that aligns with your business goals and resonates with your target customers.
